==Dutch== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|nl|dum|sollen}}, from {{der|nl|frm|soller}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nl|/ˈsɔlə(n)/}} * {{audio|nl|Nl-sollen.ogg|Audio}} ===Verb=== {{nl-verb}} # to [[throw]] back and forth {{gloss|of a ball}} # to [[play]], to [[mess]] #: {{usex|nl|We laten niet met ons '''sollen'''!|We won't let anyone '''mess''' with us!}} ====Inflection==== {{nl-conj-wk|sol|solle}} ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|goh|de}} {{m|goh|sculan}}, {{m|goh|skulan}}, from {{etyl|gem-pro|de}} {{m|gem-pro|*skulaną}}. Cognate with {{cog|en|shall}} and {{m|en|should}}, {{cog|nl|zullen}}, {{cog|da|skulle}}, {{cog|sv|skall|}} and {{m|sv|skulle}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈzɔlən/}} * {{audio|de|De-sollen.ogg|audio (Germany)}} * {{audio|de|De-at-sollen.ogg|audio (Austria)}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-irregular|soll|sollte|gesollt}} # {{lb|de|auxiliary}} [[should]]; to be [[obligated]] (to do something); [[ought]]; [[shall]] #: ''Ich '''soll''' das machen.'' — “I '''should''' do that.” #: ''Ich '''sollte''' das nicht tun.'' — “I '''should''' not do it.” # {{lb|de|auxiliary}} to be recommended (to do something); to be [[ask]]ed (to do something) # {{lb|de|auxiliary}} to be [[intend]]ed (to do something); to be meant (to be something) # {{lb|de|auxiliary}} to be said (to do something); [[reportedly]]; they say that; I hear that; so they say; rumor has it; [[supposedly]]. #: ''Es '''soll''' da viele Leute geben.'' — “They say that there are many people there.” # {{lb|de|auxiliary|in a subordinate clause in the simple past tense}} [[would]]; {{non-gloss definition|indicates that the subordinate clause indicates something that would happen in the past but after the time frame of the main clause}} # {{lb|de|auxiliary|in a subordinate clause in the subjunctive}} [[should]]; {{non-gloss definition|indicates that the subordinate clause indicates a hypothetical and unlikely condition for the main clause}} ====Usage notes==== * ''Sollen'' expresses moral duty or the suggestion that something ought to be done. {{m|de|müssen|Müssen}} can express the necessity of doing something, but also the moral duty. Both verbs can express a duty imposed by someone else. In this case ''müssen'' is stronger than ''sollen'', implying that the imposing person has some kind of power to make the other really do it. * When used as a modal auxiliary verb, the past participle is {{m|de|sollen}}. ====Conjugation==== {{de-conj|sollen|[[sollend]]|[[gesollt]] or [[sollen]]|h|[[soll]]|[[sollst]]|[[soll]]|[[sollen]]|[[sollt]]|[[sollen]]|[[sollte]]|[[solltest]]|[[sollte]]|[[sollten]]|[[solltet]]|[[sollten]]|[[solle]]|[[sollest]]|[[solle]]|[[sollen]]|[[sollet]]|[[sollen]]|[[sollte]]|[[solltest]]|[[sollte]]|[[sollten]]|[[solltet]]|[[sollten]]|''no imperative''|''no imperative''||a}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:German modal verbs]] [[Category:German preterite-present verbs]] ---- ==Luxembourgish== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|lb|gem-pro|*skulaną}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|lb|/ˈzolən/}} ===Verb=== {{lb-verb|soll|sollen}} # to [[ought]] to, [[shall]], [[should]] ====Conjugation==== {{rfinfl|lb|verb}}
